item.title: Compile
item.dc:creator: @Host_Gushers Host Gushers
item.description:
@Host_Gushers wrote:

i added this before i went into eclipse tho:

private static void addNewPlayer(Player p, Player p2, StaticPacketBuilder updateBlock) { p.getPlayersInList()[p2.getIndex()] = 1; p.getPlayerList()[p.getPlayerListSize()] = p2; p.setPlayerListSize(p.getPlayerListSize()+1); updateBlock.addBits(11, p2.getIndex()); int yPos = p2.getLocation().getY() - p.getLocation().getY(); if(yPos < 0) yPos += 32; int xPos = p2.getLocation().getX() - p.getLocation().getX(); if(xPos < 0) xPos += 32; updateBlock.addBits(1, 1); updateBlock.addBits(5, xPos); updateBlock.addBits(5, yPos); updateBlock.addBits(1, 1); updateBlock.addBits(3, 1); }

Read full topic

item.title: Compile
item.dc:creator: @Scape-JAVA Scape-JAVA
item.description:
@Scape-JAVA wrote:

Run it like you would any other server. And if you have any errors eclipse will tell you while you’re programming and it will offer advice and tips to fix it, try googling or youtubing a video with instructions. It’s really great.

Read full topic

item.description:

Read full topic

item.title: Compile
item.dc:creator: @Scape-JAVA Scape-JAVA
item.description:
@Scape-JAVA wrote:

Use an IDE. They’re much more efficient for programming private servers and not only that but they do in fact make compiling your server a much less tedious task as you don’t have to compile it. The IDE will automatically compile it for you. I personally prefer netbeans or intellij idea but you can also use eclipse. Check them out, they’re all pretty great.

Read full topic

item.title: Compile
item.dc:creator: @Flame3 John
item.description:
@Flame3 wrote:

The last sentence of that thread clearly states that you need an IDE to build on that source, because he isn’t going to provide a compiler for you.
If you want to make your own compiler, just take one from another source and edit the directories so they point towards all files you want to compile.

Read full topic
